item.title: Airtable
item.description:
Introduction to Airtable

Airtable is basically Excel on steroids. At least this is what was envisioned when Airtable was built. Now it has become a little more of a no-code monstrum that lets you do many things but at its core it is still this [insert cool adjective] Excel. The more formal way to describe this super-power Excel, is by saying: Airtable is a hybrid tool that combines the functionality of spreadsheets with the relational power of databases. This is what it is behind the scenes. In the foreground, Airtable has a visually appealing and user-friendly interface that lets anyone deal with complex data handling.

item.title: Deployment
item.description:
Multi Container Deployment on Kubernetes

Kubernetes is an open-source container orchestration platform. It can be used to automate the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

Key Concepts

  1. Pods

    • The smallest deployable unit in Kubernetes.
    • A Pod can host multiple containers that share networking and storage resources.

  2. Nodes

    • Physical or virtual machines that run Pods.
    • Components:
      • kubelet: Ensures containers are running in Pods.
      • kube-proxy: Manages networking and load balancing.
      • Container Runtime: Software responsible for running containers (e.g., Docker, containerd).

  3. Control Plane

item.title: Fullstack
item.description:
How Full Stack Applications Actually Work

Full stack applications are the backbone of modern digital experiences. They power websites, mobile apps, and online services just alike.

The term “full stack” encompasses both frontend (user-facing) and backend (server-side) components.

It is important to understand how these components interact with each other to create seamless, functional applications.

Components

  1. Frontend The visible part users interact with is called the frontend. It is usually built using a combination of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Writing a whole frontend using just these languages in their raw form would be quite tedious, which is why there are plenty frameworks that have been developed on top of them. To build the Choice of Law Dataverse we use Vue.js, which is a framework built on top of JavaScript.
